subject: Re: [junit] Preventing JUnit from stopping on failures.
msgSnippet: ... It is focused on a small bit of functionality and the asserts are not related to each other.  The functionality is the application of a CreditMemo to an
messageBody:
Jim McMaster wrote:

>
> On Tuesday, August 23, 2005 at 2:43 PM Jason Rogers said:
>
> > I'd like to chime in on this discussion just to throw a wrench in the
> > works. ;)
> >
> > First, I am of the notion that I don't generally want multiple failures
> > per test. However, there *seems* to be an assumption in this thread
> > that multilpe asserts per test are somehow related to each other, such
> > that if one fails and I fix it then the other possibly failing asserts
> > would be fixed at the same time. That is not always, and perhaps
> > generally, not the case.
>
> I believe it is, if the test is focused on a small bit of functionality.

It is focused on a small bit of functionality and the asserts are not
related to each other. The functionality is the application of a
CreditMemo to an existing sale, for which there may or may not be
related sales (eg. a purchased recurring sale, a recurring sale in
negotiation, one or more "upsales", etc.).

> Is it necessary (or even desirable) to test both these things in the same
> test? Could you perhaps do one test to show applying the CreditMemo to a
> Sale does the right thing, and a second to show applying it to a
> RecurringSale is correct? If these two actions happen in different
> classes,
> why would you need to test them at the same time?

But, that was the point. Applying it to the sale has a cascade effect
on its related sales. You could do a separate test for each thing but I
tend to hate the duplication even more! In the contrived example (based
on reality) there should be no need to directly apply the CreditMemo for
an originatingSale to one of its related sales. It happens behind the
scenes. The test is testing that the direct effect on the originating
sale takes place as well as the behind-the-scenes effect on its related
sales.

Mind you, also, that I am not truly advocating multiple failures per
test... I am playing "devil's advocate" in order to shine some light on
what seems to be forgotten territory.

--
Jason Rogers
